items.title: People who stop taking GLP-1 drugs regain weight faster, review finds
items.summary_auto: When people who are overweight and obese stopped taking their weight-loss medications they regained weight faster than those who stopped a diet or exercise program, a new review of studies finds.

items.title: Trump suspends U.S. support for 66 international organizations
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday signed an executive order suspending U.S. support for 66 organizations, agencies and commissions following his instructions for his administration to review participation in and funding for all international organizations, including those affiliated with the United Nations, according to a White House statement on social media.

items.title: Rink explosion in Alta. town last month caused by mechanical failure: investigation
items.summary_auto: A propane leak from Zamboni ice machine, not human error, caused blast that badly damaged recreation centre in Taber, Alta.

items.title: Brigitte Bardot’s funeral draws crowd in small French town
items.summary_auto: Residents and admirers applauded the funeral convoy as Brigitte Bardot's coffin was being carried through the narrow streets of Saint-Tropez. Once one of the world's most photographed women, she had long called the French Riviera resort her refuge from the celebrity that made her a household name.

items.title: Quebec’s photo radars generated record-breaking $133M in fines in 2025
items.summary_auto: The province’s Justice Ministry says mobile photo radars, which can be moved from one site to another, brought in nearly $97 million of the total amount. Some spots seem to be more lucrative than others.

items.title: Lawyer says Coquitlam, B.C., RCMP officer should be dismissed for sexist, racist group chat comments
items.summary_auto: Coquitlam RCMP Const. Mersad Mesbah testified on his own behalf at a hearing Wednesday for whether he should be dismissed from the police force for derogatory comments he made in group chats with other officers.

items.title: Netflix seemingly confirms there is no Stranger Things 'secret episode'
items.summary_auto: Netflix has ostensibly confirmed there is no “secret” Stranger Things episode set for release tonight, responding to fan speculation around a proposed finale unofficially dubbed “Conformity Gate.”

items.title: Alberta's measles case count topped 2,000 last year, and the outbreak is not over yet
items.summary_auto: Alberta's measles outbreaks sparked more than 2,000 cases of the highly infectious illness in 2025, and while transmission has dropped dramatically, experts warn the virus remains a threat in the year ahead.

items.title: Ottawa mother convicted in death of girl born on plane gets 10 years in prison
items.summary_auto: In 2020, a woman failed to take her five-year-old daughter to see a doctor for six days before the girl died in her bedroom from an untreated bladder rupture. She has now been sentenced to 10 years in prison, minus half a year already spent in custody.

items.title: Mother convicted in death of girl born on plane gets 10 years in prison
items.summary_auto: In 2020, a woman failed to take her five-year-old daughter to see a doctor for six days before the girl died in her bedroom from an untreated bladder rupture. She has now been sentenced to 10 years in prison, minus half a year already spent in custody.

items.title: Carter George hopes to inspire Thunder Bay, Ont.'s next crop of NHL talent
items.summary_auto: Thunder Bay has long been known as a hockey hotbed, sending dozens of local players to the National Hockey League, and even a pair of players to the Hockey Hall of Fame. Yet, when it comes to the annual World Junior Ice Hockey Championships, Thunder Bay’s representation is comparatively low.

items.title: Like many Ukrainians, she fled war for Quebec. Now, she fears they can’t stay
items.summary_auto: The future of many Ukrainians living in Quebec is in limbo after the provincial government cancelled a program that offered a pathway to permanent residency. Now, some are urging the government to create a special immigration program to allow them to stay.

items.title: Future of GM's CAMI plant in Ingersoll, Ont., could include military vehicles: union head
items.summary_auto: The head of the union that represents workers at the General Motors CAMI Assembly plant in Ingersoll, Ont., says switching production to military vehicles is one of the options under discussion to return the facility to operations. A GM spokesperson would only say the company is looking at different options.

items.title: ICE agent fatally shoots woman during immigration crackdown in Minneapolis
items.summary_auto: A U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer shot and killed a Minneapolis motorist on Wednesday during the Trump administration's latest immigration crackdown on a major American city — a shooting that federal officials claimed was an act of self-defence but that the city's mayor described as "reckless" and unnecessary.

items.title: 6 charts that tell the story of Venezuela's struggling oil economy
items.summary_auto: Following the capture of President Nicolás Maduro, global attention has shifted to the White House’s next move in the region. To understand the stakes of this transition, here are six charts that illustrate the scale and significance of Venezuela’s oil reserves.

items.title: Investigation into dog attack that killed N.S. boy continuing, RCMP say
items.summary_auto: Drew Nickerson, 13, died after being airlifted to a Halifax hospital.

items.title: Canadians Seth Rogen, Catherine O'Hara and Martin Short nominated for Actor Awards
items.summary_auto: Canadians have collected a handful of nominations for the Actor Awards, SAG-AFTRA's annual accolades honouring Hollywood's best film and television/streaming performances of the year.

items.title: New dietary guide from Trump administration flips food pyramid for Americans to eat more protein
items.summary_auto: The administration of U.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday announced a new slate of dietary guidelines that recommends Americans eat more protein and less sugar than previously advised and that consumers avoid highly processed foods to achieve a healthy diet.

items.title: Video game giant Ubisoft closes Halifax studio, cutting 71 jobs
items.summary_auto: Staff formed company's first North American union in late December but Ubisoft says unionization did not influence closure.

items.title: Tim Hortons inks partnerships with Canadian Olympic, Paralympic Committees
items.summary_auto: Tim Hortons might be synonymous with hockey but this year, it's clinching a new sporting title: Olympic sponsor.

items.title: Man who defaced Holocaust Monument won't serve more time behind bars
items.summary_auto: The former City of Ottawa lawyer who defaced the National Holocaust Monument with blood-red paint last summer won't serve any more time behind bars.

items.title: Greenland has become the island that could break NATO
items.summary_auto: European leaders have sounded the alarm over Donald Trump’s ambitions to take over Greenland, but the U.S. president may instead be thinking of his legacy. If that’s the case, many analysts, diplomats and politicians believe not only will European diplomacy fail, but the entire post-Second World War system of alliances will come crashing down alongside it, should the U.S. move unilaterally.

items.title: Alberta government launches website to host information about proposed oil pipeline
items.summary_auto: Government says it plans to have an application ready by July 1 to the federal major projects office, which aims to expedite infrastructure projects deemed in the nation's interest.

items.title: Nick Reiner's lawyer, Alan Jackson, asks to leave murder case, delaying arraignment
Rare mountain gorilla twins born in the wild
items.summary_auto: A mountain gorilla has given birth to twins in war-ravaged eastern Congo, a national park announced on Wednesday, in what it described as "a major event" for the endangered subspecies.

items.title: Quebec Superior Court approves class action against Ticketmaster over service fees
items.summary_auto: The Quebec Superior Court has authorized a class-action lawsuit against Ticketmaster that accuses the American company of charging abusive service fees on ticket sales.

items.title: U.S. seeks to assert its control over Venezuelan oil with tanker seizures, global sales
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump's administration on Wednesday sought to assert its control over Venezuelan oil, seizing a pair of sanctioned tankers transporting petroleum and announcing plans to relax some sanctions so the U.S. can oversee the sale of Venezuela's oil worldwide.

items.title: U.S. Secretary of State Rubio says he will meet with Denmark amid European alarm over Greenland rhetoric
items.summary_auto: U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Wednesday said that he would meet with Denmark next week, as U.S. President Donald Trump has repeated in recent days that he wants to gain control of Greenland.

items.title: Warner Bros. rejects revised Paramount bid, tells shareholders to stay with Netflix
items.summary_auto: Warner Bros. Discovery's board has unanimously turned down Paramount Skydance's latest attempt to acquire the studio, saying its revised $108.4-billion US hostile bid amounted to a risky leveraged buyout that investors should reject. The board repeated their commitment to Netflix's offer, which they say offers more value and certainty.

items.title: An unusually severe flu season is pushing hospitals in northeastern Ontario beyond capacity
No Yukon Quest sled dog race this year, say former board members
items.summary_auto: Mushers and former board members say the Yukon Quest is cancelled this year, because there is no one left to organize the iconic sled dog race.

items.title: Pharmacare claims for Ozempic have soared in Manitoba in last 4 years, provincial data shows
items.summary_auto: With generic versions of the weight-loss drug Ozempic expected to hit the Canadian market this year, provincial data shows the number of times the medication has been dispensed from pharmacies across Manitoba has more than quadrupled over the past four years.

items.title: GTA home sales fell 11.2% last year compared to 2024, report says
items.summary_auto: Home sales dropped 11.2 per cent in the Greater Toronto Area last year compared to that of 2024, according to a new report released Wednesday.

items.title: Why Heated Rivalry's Team Canada fleece is taking the internet by storm
items.summary_auto: Desire for a Heated Rivalry-inspired Team Canada fleece came to a head recently after eagle-eyed fans spotted — and gushed over — a particular outfit choice by character Shane Hollander. And they've been demanding the opportunity to buy it ever since.

items.title: Cornwall shooting sheds light on intimate partner violence among seniors, shelter says
items.summary_auto: A fatal weekend shooting in Cornwall, Ont., is shedding a stark spotlight on a segment of the population whose experience of intimate partner violence has only recently been recognized for what it is, a local women's shelter says.

items.title: Canadian tourists voice concerns over Caribbean travel after U.S. strike on Venezuela
items.summary_auto: Travellers planning trips to the Caribbean are voicing trepidation online after the U.S. strike on Venezuela that captured president Nicolás Maduro, while one Latin America expert says it's not a good time to travel to the region.

items.title: Marco Rubio's fingerprints are all over Trump's Venezuela plan. Here's why
items.summary_auto: When Marco Rubio took the lectern at Mar-a-Lago shortly after U.S. President Donald Trump announced the country had captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro, it was the culmination of a decade of effort from the secretary of state and a clear sign that he had emerged as a leading voice within the Trump administration.

items.title: The U.S. imposed a blockade on sanctioned oil tankers tied to Venezuela. How is that working out?
items.summary_auto: Questioned over the weekend about how the U.S. government will take over governing Venezuela, Secretary of State Marco Rubio instead shifted the focus to the U.S. blockade of sanctioned oil tankers. CBC News looks at the origins of the blockade, what it entails, whether it's considered legal and just how effective it is.

items.title: 'Death ball' sponge, tiny opossum among cool new species of 2025
items.summary_auto: A spider with extraordinary genitalia, a carnivorous caterpillar that wears its prey's body parts, and a tiny opossum are among the cool new species described by science in 2025.

items.title: Turbulence is getting worse. Would it be better if planes looked more like birds?
items.summary_auto: Pilots can’t see it coming, and it’s hard to avoid. But severe clear-air turbulence can shake a plane ‘like King Kong.’ It’s on the rise, and forecast to get worse due to climate change. The rise has researchers investigating how to better predict clear-air turbulence, and looking to the physics of birds to make this chaotic force less dangerous.

items.title: Why everyone is talking about Heated Rivalry's Team Canada fleece
items.summary_auto: Desire for a Heated Rivalry-inspired Team Canada fleece came to a head recently after eagle-eyed fans spotted — and gushed over — a particular outfit choice by character Shane Hollander. And they've been demanding the opportunity to buy it ever since.
